e4: While I value honesty in financial reporting, abruptly shifting to a new policy risks misleading retail investors who have historically adjusted for the bias. Their lack of awareness could lead to investment decisions based on inaccurate information.  Further investigation into investor education strategies might be warranted before making such a drastic change.
e5: An ethical reporting policy prioritizes transparency and accuracy. It delivers information in a clear, understandable manner, free from intentional manipulation or omissions. Importantly, it anticipates the potential impact on all stakeholders –  sophisticated and retail investors alike – and seeks to minimize harm arising from any transitions or changes.  Furthermore, ongoing communication and investor education are crucial components of an ethical framework.
e6: Yes, I would have several follow-up questions for management. First, what strategies can be employed to effectively communicate a policy change to all investors, not just sophisticated ones? Second, could we explore alternative reporting frameworks that achieve transparency while mitigating potential investor harm during the transition? Finally, are there legal experts who specialize in this kind of scenario we could consult with for guidance?
